C and E are correct.

choices.B: The concatenation operator || is always evaluated before addition and subtraction in an expression.
choices.D: NULLS influence the precedence of operators in an expression.
choices.C: Multiple parentheses can be used to override the default precedence of operators in an expression.
choices.A: The + binary operator has the highest precedence in an expression in a SQL statement.
choices.E: Arithmetic operators with equal precedence are evaluated from left to right within an expression.

questions.question_text: Which two statements will return the names of the three employees with the lowest salaries? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
A. select last_name, salary from employees
fetch first 3 rows only 
order by salary;
- results in an error
---------------------------------------------
B. select last_name, salary from ( select * from employees order by salary)
where rownum <= 3;
- works
-------------------------------------------------------
c. select last_name, salary from employees
order by salary
 fetch first 3 rows only ;
- works
----------------------------------------------------------------
D. select last_name, salary from employees where rownum <= 3 order by salary;
- returns the first 3 rows and orders the 3 rows based on salary so its incorrect
-------------------------------------------------------
E. select last_name, salary from employees where rownum <= 3 order by (select salary from employees);
- subquery returns more than one row so results in error

comments.content: thx, u made me facepalm cuz I forgot that, thx again 4 help

discussion.content:
D is wrong
after order by rownum might not anymore be sequential.

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer

choices.D: It will return rows common to both SELECT statements.
choices.A: It will return rows from both SELECT statements including duplicate rows.
choices.B: It will return rows from both SELECT statements after eliminating duplicate rows.
choices.C: It will return rows that are not common to both SELECT statements.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
union all includes duplicates

questions.question_text:
You need to allow user ANDREW to:
1. Modify the TITLE and ADDRESS columns of your CUSTOMERS table.
2. GRANT that permission to other users.
Which statement will do this?

choices.D: GRANT UPDATE ON customers.title, customers.address TO andrew WITH ADMIN OPTION;
choices.F: GRANT UPDATE (title, address) ON customers TO andrew WITH ADMIN OPTION;
choices.C: GRANT UPDATE (title, address) ON customers TO andrew WITH GRANT OPTION;
choices.B: GRANT UPDATE (title, address) ON customers TO andrew;
choices.A: GRANT UPDATE ON customers.title, customers.address TO andrew;
choices.E: GRANT UPDATE ON customers.title, customers.address TO andrew WITH GRANT OPTION;

discussion.content: C is correct: WITH GRANT OPTION is necessary in this case

Selected Answer: C
C. GRANT UPDATE (title, address) ON customers TO andrew WITH GRANT OPTION;

Selected Answer: C
C is correct (GRANT option is for object privileges):
GRANT UPDATE (title, address) ON customers TO andrew WITH GRANT OPTION

E is not correct (ADMIN option is for system privileges):
GRANT UPDATE (title, address) ON customers TO andrew WITH ADMIN OPTION
gives the error ORA-00993: missing GRANT keyword.

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer. 

https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/sqlrf/GRANT.html#GUID-20B4E2C0-A7F8-4BC8-A5E8-BE61BDC41AC3__I2126048

Selected Answer: C
The answer is C.
C is for Cat.

Selected Answer: C
Yes, this is the correct syntax according to some sites
C is correct
Why is E not correct?

Selected Answer: E
E is also correct

C is correct!

WITH GRANT OPTION
now the user ANDREW can give grants to other users.
GRANT UPDATE(TITLE) ON CUSTOMERS TO HR;
If REVOKE UPDATE(TITLE,ADDRESS) ON CUSTOMERS FROM ANDREW
is executed then eventually HR will also lose the grants.

C is correct.
The owner of an object can grant it to another user by specifying the WITH GRANT OPTION clause in the GRANT statement. In this case, the new grantee can then grant the same level of access to other users or roles. Here are three points to keep in mind about the WITH GRANT OPTION clause:

https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/oracle-database-administration/1565925165/ch06s01s05s01.html#:~:text=The%20owner%20of%20an%20object,to%20other%20users%20or%20roles.
C is correct
